unit_learning_outcomes.description: Be able to critically analyse, interpret and assess the contribution of cases, treaties and institutions to the development of international environmental law;
Demonstrate a thorough understanding of the basic functions and overarching global principles of international environmental law including sustainable development and transboundary harm
Recognise and recall the key institutions and actors involved in international environmental law, understand their respective roles in establishing and maintaining environmental governance
Critically evaluate arguments on ways to improve international environmental law;

Engage in debate surrounding contemporary and emergent issues in the discipline including cooperation between different treaty regimes; linkage between law and scientific knowledge and the challenges of the Anthropocene;
Identify intersections and interactions between international environmental law and other areas of international law, such as trade, human rights, development assistance.

Build a sophisticated understanding of the contextual factors (such as economic development) that can influence the participation of nation states in international environmental law from the perspective of the Global North and Global South

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Students will spend this time preparing for the designated tasks listed for each tutorial
Students will spend this time completing the prescribed readings

enrolment_rules.description: (80cp in LAW or LAWS units including LAWS2000 or LAWS259 or LAW459) or (130cp including LAWS2000 or LAWS259 or LAW459)

assessments.description: Students will prepare and participate in relevant discussion during tutorials including resolving problem based tasks
Students will prepare a research essay that analyses a topic of environmental law.
Students will submit responses to questions based on a hypothetical scenario

data.subject_search_title: LAWS5069 - Energy and Natural Resources Law
data.description: This unit introduces students to international environmental law and governance, a burgeoning and specialised field of public international law. International environmental law manages the interaction of humankind and the environment from a global perspective. The unit explores the legal response of nation states, international institutions such as the United Nations and other relevant global actors to regulate the transboundary aspects of environmental change. Students will cover the historical development of international environmental law, the need for a cooperative, global response and the effectiveness of sustainable development. Several important treaty regimes covering issues such as ozone depletion, climate change and biodiversity are explored in addition to pivotal international case law and arbitration decisions.
data.search_title: LAWS5069 - Energy and Natural Resources Law
